journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: The response of the rider’s body to roll oscillations of two wheeled vehicles; experimental tests and biomechanical models

contrib-group.aff: Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Padova, Italy

author-notes.corresp: A Doria, Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Padova, Via Venezia, 1, University of Padova, Padova, Italy. Email: alberto.doria@unipd.it

abstract.p: This paper deals with a research aimed to identify the biomechanical properties of the rider’s body from laboratory tests. Special test equipment has been developed; it is a motorcycle mock up driven by a hydraulic servo-actuator that generates oscillations in the range 0.5–10 Hz. When the rider rides the motorcycle mock up, a system of sensors measures the input motion and the response of the rider’s body. The response of the rider’s body is represented in the frequency domain by means of frequency response functions: the motion frequency response function describes the lean motion of the rider’s trunk, the torque frequency response function describes the torque applied by the rider on the handlebars. The measured frequency response functions are used for identifying the parameters of lumped mass biomechanical models, which are suited to integration with the multi-body model of the motorcycle. Many experimental results are presented and discussed. Various biomechanical models are evaluated in terms of capability of reproducing the measured frequency response function. A good fitting of the motion frequency response function is achieved by means of a three-degrees-of-freedom model of the rider’s trunk, whereas a good fitting of the torque frequency response function is achieved by means of a five-degrees-of-freedom model of trunk and arms.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In motorcycles and scooters the mass of the rider (and passenger) is a significant fraction of the total mass of the system; in bicycles the rider’s mass is much larger than the vehicle’s mass. Hence, the rider influences the dynamic behaviour of the vehicle not only by means of voluntary control actions, but also by means of passive response of his/her body to motorcycle oscillations. Actually, the rider’s body has inertial, stiffness and damping characteristics that combine with motorcycle characteristics to determine the dynamic behaviour of the whole system. In particular the stabilization of dangerous oscillations typical of two-wheeled vehicles (weave and wobble1,2,3) is affected by the rider’s characteristics. For these reasons, advanced simulation of two-wheeled vehicles requires detailed information about rider biomechanical properties, which makes it possible the development of the multi-body model of the whole system.

Recent studies in the field of motorcycles4 and in the collateral fields of cars5 and aircraft,6 have shown that a model of the rider’s body, composed of some rigid bodies (e.g. the upper and lower body) with lumped stiffness and damping elements in the articulations, is enough to obtain a large improvement in the results of simulations. Actually, a cumbersome multi-body model of the whole rider with detailed representation of every limb and articulation7 at the present does not seem to be essential for a good motorcycle simulation, because the motion of several articulations is negligible and there are other important phenomena, like the activation of the muscular regions and reflex dynamics.8 It is worth highlighting that lumped element models are used also for the calculation of the vertical transmissibility of the human body in the sitting and standing positions.9

Inertial properties of the multi-body model of the rider can be calculated from those of the limbs obtained from specific research in the field of anthropometry.10 The stiffness and damping properties of the articulations are more difficult to determine and depend on the level of activation of the various muscular regions. For these reasons the best way to identify these properties is to perform vibration tests on a sample of riders and to calculate stiffness and damping properties from the characteristics of measured vibrations.

After the pioneer research of Katayama et al.,11,12 very little research have been carried out to identify the properties of the rider’s body from road tests13 and from laboratory tests. The research approach adopted by the Motorcycle Dynamics Research Group (MDRG) of Padova University consists in measuring the response of the rider’s body to different inputs by means of specific laboratory tests. The different inputs excite different muscular regions and make it possible to identify specific damping and stiffness properties of the body; for example, torsion stiffness about the steer axis can be identified from the tests with imposed steer oscillations, whereas the lean stiffness can be identified from the test with imposed roll oscillations. The results obtained with steer excitation have been presented by Cossalter et al.,4 and the integration of the motorcycle model with the biomechanical model of steering impedance has given good results.

The present research focuses on the response of the rider’s body to roll oscillations. The first part of the paper deals with the special testing equipment developed to carry out roll tests, and shows and discusses many experimental results. The second part of the paper deals with the development of lumped-mass models of the rider. The models have to be able to explain the measured behaviour of the rider and at the same time have to be rather simple, in order to make easier their integration with the multi-body model of the motorcycle. Advanced multi-body models for motorcycle and bicycle simulation are presented in Cossalter et al.,14 Sharp et al.15 and Schwab,16 respectively.

sec.title: Testing equipment
sec.p: The identification in the laboratory of the properties of the rider’s body, which influence the dynamic behaviour of the system composed of the vehicle and rider, requires the development of special equipment able to generate oscillation similar to the ones of a motorcycle and to guarantee the correct posture of the rider. The latter issue is important, since the activation of the various muscular regions may depend on posture. A test with posture different from the one of a motorcyclist may lead to results not useful for motorcycle simulation.

To satisfy the above-mentioned requirements a modular testing equipment has been developed: it consists of a high performance hydraulic shaker, a motorcycle mock-up, a system of sensors and a data acquisition system. The motorcycle mock-up (see Figure 1) is a frame that can roll about a horizontal axis in order to simulate the roll oscillations of the motorcycle. It is equipped with handlebars (which cannot rotate about the steer axis), saddle, fuel tank and foot rests. These devices assure the correct posture of the rider. The hydraulic actuator (built by Moog Italiana (Malnate, Italy)) is equipped with a two-stage valve, which is able to operate up to 50 Hz, and it is controlled in a closed loop with position feedback (a position transducer is mounted in the stem). The reference signals are generated by a LabView code.

In the framework of this research the range of frequency of interest is from 0.5 Hz to 10 Hz, because it includes the typical frequencies of weave and wobble. The response of the rider’s body in this range of frequencies was studied performing a frequency sweep excitation9 with a duration of 115 s. A frequency sweep test gives a measurement of the frequency response function (FRF) less accurate than the one given by a stepped sine test, but the time required for carrying out the test is much smaller. For this reason a frequency sweep with a low speed rate appeared adequate to carry out a large number of tests on a sample of riders. The shaker is position controlled. On the one hand, if the amplitude were kept constant, acceleration at high frequency would be very large and annoying, on the other hand a strong reduction in the amplitude at high frequency is not practical, because the shaker has a limited resolution. In order to obtain a good compromise, the amplitude of the frequency sweep was decreased when the frequency increased, dividing the initial amplitude by the square root of the instantaneous angular frequency, according to the following equation
in which A0 is initial amplitude, t is time and the derivative of the argument of the sine function is the instantaneous angular frequency.

Generally speaking the response of the rider’s body to roll oscillations is a lean motion with a complex pattern of deflections that involve the whole trunk. Some preliminary researches and tests11,12,17 showed that the trunk can be considered a rigid body elastically connected to the motorcycle through the arms and the waist. In this research an improvement is made in modelling by considering the trunk composed of two rigid segments elastically connected. The rigid body motion of each segment of the trunk is characterized by the angular velocity and by the linear velocity of a reference point, which can be considered the origin of the segment fixed frame.

From the point of view of measurement, angular velocity has the advantage of being a global property of the trunk segment, which is slightly influenced by local contractions or vibrations of the body’s surface, whereas the measurement of linear velocity is influenced by local phenomena and requires the definition of a reference point, which may be difficult. Another advantage of angular velocity is that the measurement system does not impose any constraint on the motion of the trunk. The measurement of rotations, which was carried out in the previous researches,11–13 required the presence of a linkage attached between the rider’s body and the motorcycle mock-up that constrained the motion of the rider’s trunk.

For the above-mentioned reasons the sensor system was rather simple and included only two rate gyros and a custom made torque meter. The rate gyros (typical range ± 200°/s, typical sensitivity 25 mVs/°) were used for measuring the amplitude of the excitation (roll rate of the motorcycle mock-up) and the response of the rider’s body. In this case the sensor was fixed to an aluminum back plate that was fastened by means of straps to the rider’s chest at the level of the sternum. The posture of the rider and the position of the rate gyros were recorded by means of photographs. The axis of the rate gyro placed on the rider’s chest was not parallel to the roll axis of the mock motorcycle, but it was roughly parallel to the axis of rotation of the upper body with respect to the lower body.

The custom made torque meter was used for measuring the torque exerted by the rider’s arms on the handlebars about an axis parallel to the roll axis of the motorcycle mock-up. The torque meter was realized by mounting the handlebars on a ball bearing with axis parallel to the roll axis and preventing rotation by means of a traction-compression load cell inserted between the handlebars and a plate fixed to the front pillar of the motorcycle mock-up; the sensitivity of the load cell is 2 mV/V. Since there is an offset, hhb, of 0.23 m between the handles and the centre of the ball joint (see Figure 1), the measured torque (Mhb) depends both on lateral force, Fy, and on the torque, Mx, that the rider applies to the handlebars. Torque, Mhb, is a good index of how much the rider tends to cling to the motorcycle.

Measured data (time records) were analyzed in the frequency domain, and frequency response functions (FRFs) were calculated. The motion FRF is the ratio between the angular velocity of the trunk about an axis perpendicular to the rider’s back and the roll rate of the motorcycle mock-up; it is a non-dimensional number. The torque FRF is the ratio between the measured torque and the roll rate of the motorcycle mock-up. The measured FRFs depend on the poles and zeros of the system. In order to identify the biomechanical properties, the FRFs can be fitted by multiple degree-of-freedom (DOF) models of the rider’s body, as in modal testing.

sec.title: Experimental results
sec.p: The tests were carried out on a sample of five riders with different physiques and riding experiences. The initial amplitude of the sweep excitation was set to 4 mm, which corresponded to a roll angle of 1.5°.

sec.title: Preliminary tests
sec.p: Since the response of a human is considered, repeatability of results was first assessed. Figure 2 shows the moduli and phases of the motion FRFs measured in some tests carried out in the same conditions by rider 1. In the plots the mean value and standard deviation are represented as well. Repeatability is good; the largest values of standard deviation of modulus and phase appear in the range 4–7 Hz and 0.5–1 Hz, respectively.

caption.p: Repeatability of motion frequency response function: rider 1.

sec.p: Figure 3 shows the torque FRFs (in Nms/°) measured in the same tests. Also in this case repeatability is good, with the maximum standard deviation of modulus at about 5 Hz and the maximum standard deviation of phase at about 4 Hz.

caption.p: Repeatability of torque frequency response function: rider 1.

sec.p: Since the tests carried out with the other riders also showed good repeatability, in the rest of the paper the behaviour of each rider is represented by the plots of the mean modulus and phase of the FRFs measured in a set (3–5) of similar tests.

sec.title: Tests in normal conditions
sec.p: When these tests were performed, the riders were instructed to grasp the handlebars with a moderate force without clinging to the motorcycle. Figure 4 shows the mean modulus and phase of the motion FRFs of the five riders.

caption.p: Mean motion frequency response functions of the five riders.

sec.p: At very low frequency (<1 Hz) time domain signals are rather irregular (perhaps voluntary control of the rider plays an important role); nevertheless the tendencies shown by the FRFs are clear: modulus tends to 2 and phase tends to 0. These results agree with the fact that at very low frequency the rider moves almost in phase with the motorcycle mock-up and the roll rotation of the trunk is larger than the one of the motorcycle mock-up, owing to the effect of gravity. Then, the modulus of the FRF suddenly increases at 1 Hz and shows a resonance peak at about 2 Hz. The peak amplitude depends on the rider and ranges from 3.5 to 5.5. In resonance the phase lag is larger than 200°. After the resonance peak, the FRF modulus maintains large values and in some riders there is a minor peak in the range 4.5–6 Hz. Above 6 Hz FRF modulus decreases markedly.
These results, and in particular the large phase lags, may be related to the presence of some closed modes of vibration generating the main peak, and to the reflex of the postural muscles.
The standard deviations of the sample of riders are presented in the same Figure 4; they are significantly larger than the one of the single rider.

Figure 5 shows the mean modulus and phase of the FRFs between the measured torque and the roll velocity of the mock motorcycle. At very low frequency the modulus is rather irregular and it ranges between 0.5 and 1.5, depending on the rider; the effect of voluntary control may be important. Then the plot is characterized by the presence of two minima (at 2 Hz and 8 Hz) and one maximum (at 5 Hz) which do not correspond to the maxima and minima of the motion FRF (Figure 4). This phenomenon may occur because only a part of the torque needed to move the rider’s body passes through the handlebars.

caption.p: Mean torque frequency response functions of the five riders.

sec.p: Even in the case of torque FRF, the standard deviation of the sample of riders is larger than the one of the single rider.

sec.title: Tests with increased grasping force
sec.p: Since studies of the steering task showed a different neuromuscular behaviour of the ‘co-contracted’ driver,5 differences between the response of the relaxed and ‘co-contracted’ rider are expected in the riding task as well.

For this reason some tests were performed in which the riders were instructed to grasp the handlebars with a large force. Figure 6 shows the mean modulus and phase of the motion FRFs of the five riders.

caption.p: Mean motion frequency response functions of the five riders, increased grasping force.

sec.p: All the curves, except the one of rider 4, show that the sharp increase in the modulus takes place at a frequency higher than in the previous tests (see Figure 4). The mean value of the FRFs of the sample of riders is 3 at 2 Hz, whereas in the previous case this value was reached at 1.25 Hz. With increased grasping force, the peak amplitude decreases by about 15% in riders 1 and 4 and does not shows large variations in the other riders. These phenomena are in agreement with an increase in the stiffness caused by the contracted muscles of the arms.
The phase plot shows that at low frequency the phase lag is smaller than in the previous case.

Figure 7 shows the torque FRFs. The range of large amplitudes (maximum value 3 Nms/°) extends up to 2.5 Hz. The first minimum is at about 4 Hz. In the rest of the interval of frequencies the FRF modulus is about 1 Nms/°, this value is close to the maximum value measured in the tests with standard grasping force. The presence of large differences between Figures 5 and 7 in the low frequency range agrees with the fact that the rider is able to control his arms when the frequency is low.

caption.p: Mean torque frequency response functions of the five riders, increased grasping force.

sec.title: Models of the rider’s body
sec.p: This section describes models of the rider’s body that can be used for simulating his roll response and for identifying his stiffness and damping characteristics. The equations of motion were developed with the Lagrange method and were solved considering small oscillations caused by harmonic roll rotation of the motorcycle mock-up. The FRFs were calculated with the aid of software for algebraic manipulation of equations.

sec.title: 1-DOF model
sec.p: The first model has 1-DOF plus roll rotation of the motorcycle (input motion) and it is a simplification of the model presented by Katajama et al.11 (see Figure 8 and consider yR=0). The lower body of the rider (mass m1) is assumed to be fixed to the motorcycle mock-up. The upper body of the rider (trunk, head and arms) is represented as a unique rigid body. It can rotate (rotation φR) with respect to the motorcycle mock-up about an axis perpendicular to the rider’s back (body lean axis) and tilted by an angle, α, with respect of the roll axis of the mock motorcycle (in the model presented in Katajama et al.11α was always zero). A rotational spring (stiffness kφ) and a damper (coefficient cφ) oppose the rotation, φR, and angular velocity, φ·R, respectively. They represent the stiffness and damping properties of the waist and arms, which are assumed to be in parallel and to generate torques in the plane perpendicular to the body lean axis. For the sake of simplicity the damper is not represented in Figure 8. During the experimental tests roll rate, φ·, and absolute angular velocity of the rider’s trunk, φ·T, were measured by means of the rate gyros. The latter velocity includes the velocity, φ·R, due to the relative rotation of the upper body with respect to the lower body and a component of roll velocity
Equation (3) shows the calculated motion FRF between the absolute angular velocity of the rider and the angular velocity of motorcycle mock up

The analysis of equation (3) shows that the motion FRF of the 1-DOF model has two poles and two zeros; hence it is able to represent the most important resonance peak of Figures 4 and 6. The inertial and geometric properties that appear in equation (2) are: upper body mass, m2, moment of inertia, Jxx2 (with respect to an axis parallel to the lean axis and passing through the centre of mass), height of revolute joint, h1, and centre of mass height, hg2.

sec.title: 2-DOF model
sec.p: The second model has 2-DOF plus roll rotation of the motorcycle and it similar to the model presented by Katajama et al.,11 but the translating mass of the upper body is neglected.

Figure 8 shows that the trunk is represented by a unique rigid body that can translate (yR) and rotate with respect to the motorcycle. The new biomechanical parameters are linear stiffness, ky, and damping, cy. The FRF (equation (4)) has four poles and three zeros

In the models of Figure 8, rotational stiffness, kφ, and damping, cφ, and lateral stiffness, ky, and damping, cy, are equivalent parameters that take into account the effect of both the waist and the arms, which are supposed to deflect in parallel.

sec.title: 3-DOF model
sec.p: During the tests it was often observed that the upper part of the trunk moved in a different way from the rest of the trunk, and that at certain frequencies it tended to maintain an upright position. The measured FRFs present some properties (large phase lags) that are compatible with the presence of more than two modes of vibration of the trunk. Hence, in the third model the trunk is divided into two parts by a new revolute joint with axis parallel to the body lean axis, the new relative rotation is named ψR (see Figure 9(a)). Parameter h2 defines the position of the new revolute joint. A rotational spring (stiffness kψ) and a rotational damper (damping coefficient cψ) opposes ψR and velocity ψ·R, respectively.

Since it is very difficult to make a measurement of the inertial properties of the two segments of the trunk, the trunk is simply divided into two parts with equal mass (m2 = m3), which are connected by a revolute joint located at the centre of mass of the whole trunk. The centre of mass of the two parts coincides with the centre of mass of the whole trunk, and the moments of inertia of two parts (Jxx2 and Jxx3) give the moment of inertia of the whole trunk (about its centre of mass).
The equations of motion of the 3-DOF model in matrix form are

[ M ]
,
[ C ]
,
[ K ]
are the mass, damping and stiffness matrices of the system, {V} is a vector of forcing terms that depends on the roll motion of the motorcycle mock-up. The gravity terms appear in the stiffness matrix and in the forcing vector. The matrices are reported in Appendix 2.

If harmonic roll oscillations of the motorcycle mock-up are considered, the motion FRF can be calculated. In this case it is the ratio between absolute angular velocity of the upper trunk (ψ·T) and roll rate (φ·). Angular velocity ψ·T is given by
With this model the motion FRF has 5 zeros and 6 poles.

sec.title: 5-DOF model
sec.p: The behaviour of the rider’s arms is rather complex and the videos of the tests and the reports of the riders highlights that the arms cannot be considered simple stiffness and damping elements that connect the trunk with the handlebars.

For this reason, starting from the 3-DOF model of the trunk, a model of the rider with a more detailed description of the arms has been developed (see Figure 9). The inertial properties of arms are represented by two lumped masses located at the elbows; their total mass is m4. The upper arms and forearms are represented by spring–damper systems. This model has 9-DOF plus roll rotation of the motorcycle, but the number of DOF can be decreased considering only the most important motions of the arms (with respect to the motorcycle mock-up), which are perceived by the riders and recorded in the videos of tests. Actually only two motions of the arms appear important. The first is a translational motion in the lateral direction with the elbows that move in phase. The second is a sort of torsion motion of the arms with the elbows that move in opposition in a direction roughly parallel to the rider’s back. In order to take into account these motions only, the model of the arms can be simplified connecting the elbows by means of a massless bar that can translate in the lateral direction and rotate about an axis parallel to the lean axis. The yaw rotation of the bar and the vertical and longitudinal translations are neglected.

Figure 9(b) is a top view of the rider model in which the lateral components of stiffness and damping of upper arms (ka,ca) and forearms (kf,cf) are represented; the lateral displacement of elbows masses is named yE. Figure 9(c) is a view of the rider model in a plane parallel to the rider’s trunk; θE is the rotation of the bar (connecting the elbows) with respect to the motorcycle mock-up. The components of stiffness and damping of the upper arms in this plane generate elastic and viscous torques that oppose to the relative rotation between the bar and the trunk (θE−ψR), the equivalent rotational stiffness and damping are named kθa,cθa, respectively. The components of stiffness and damping of the forearms generate elastic and viscous torques that oppose the rotation of the bar with respect to the motorcycle mock-up (θE); the equivalent rotational stiffness and damping are kθf,cθf.
Masses, springs and dampers have been associated to specific parts of the arms, but, as in other biomechanical models,18 they can represent a more general behaviour.
The equation of motion of the 5-DOF model in matrix form is

[ M ]
,
[ C ]
,
[ K ]
are the mass, damping and stiffness matrices of the system, {V} is a vector of forcing terms that depends on the roll motion of the motorcycle mock-up. They are reported in Appendix 2.

The analysis of the matrices of the system shows that torsion rotation of the arms, θE, and lateral displacement of the elbows, yE, are coupled to the trunk through the stiffness and damping matrices only.
If harmonic roll oscillations of the motorcycle mock-up are considered, the motion and the torque FRF can be calculated.
The torque that the arms generate on the handlebars depends both on the lateral force and on the torsion torque; the following equation holds

in which Mhb0 is the complex amplitude of torque, yE0 is the complex amplitude of elbow lateral displacement and θE0 is the complex amplitude of torsion rotation of arms. The first term of equation (7) accounts for the lateral force that passes at distance hhb from the ball bearing that connects the handlebars with the motorcycle mock-up. The second term accounts for the torsion couple exerted by the forearms on the handlebars. Coefficient cos(α) takes into account that this couple lies in a plane parallel to the plane of the rider’s back.

sec.title: Identification results
sec.p: The mass characteristics of the biomechanical models of the rider’s body were calculated from the body segments parameters found by Dempster and presented in Robertson et al.10 Dempster’s parameters include for each segment the ratio between the segment mass and the total mass of the rider, the ratio between the centre of mass length and segment length and the ratio between radius of gyration and segment length. Results obtained from Dempster’s parameters are in good agreement both with the results obtained by Hanavan with the geometrical modelling method,19 and with the results obtained in 2011 with the angular momentum technique.20 A specific code was developed to calculate the upper body centre of mass and moment of inertia about an axis parallel to the lean axis and passing through the centre of mass, taking into account the contributions of trunk, head, upper arms and forearms. The inputs of the code are the measured positions of shoulders, elbows, hands and buttocks, which define the posture of the rider and in particular the inclination of the rider’s body (see Figure 10).

caption.p: Model for the calculation of upper body mass properties.

sec.p: The damping and stiffness parameters of the various models of the rider’s body were identified by means of a best fitting technique developed in MATLAB. The penalty function is composed by two terms. The first term is related to the motion FRF, the second to the torque frequency response function (FRFτ)
Weighting factors wm and wτ make it possible to modulate the importance of the two terms.

The FRFs are complex functions. The fitting may be carried out either by minimizing the difference between the two complex vectors that represent (for each value of frequency) the measured frequency response function (FRFm(fi) or FRFτm(fi)) and the calculated frequency response function (FRF(fi,x) or FRFτ(fi,x)), or by minimizing the difference between the modules and the phases of the two functions. In this research the second option is chosen, because it gives the possibility of weighting in different ways the modulus and phase errors, which is useful for the specific application.
Therefore, the two terms of the penalty function are given by the following equations

They depend on a vector of unknown biomechanical stiffness and damping parameters (x) and are evaluated for a set of values of frequency fi (typically 50–100). Factors wmφ and wτφ are used for weighting the phase error, taking into account that the modulus and phase have different ranges.
When the 1-, 2- and 3-DOF models are used for fitting the motion FRF, wτ is set to zero. When the 5-DOF model is used for fitting, both the motion and the torque FRF wm≠0 and wτ≠0.
The errors in the fitting of the modulus em and phase eφ of the motion FRF are defined according to these equations
Similar fitting errors are defined for the torque FRF.

The aim of this research is the definition of a model of the rider’s body able to represent the measured response of a wide population of riders and suited to implementation in the multi-body model of the vehicle. For these reasons, the various models described earlier are evaluated considering their ability to fit the mean FRFs of the sample of riders, because in this way a more general result is obtained. The mean mass characteristics of the sample of riders are calculated starting from the mean weight and mean positions of shoulders and elbows.

sec.title: Tests in normal conditions
sec.p: Figure 11 shows the fitting of experimental data by means of the various models above. When the 1-DOF model is considered, the rigid body that rotates about the lean axis includes trunk, head, arms and forearms. The definition of inertial parameters m2,Jxx2,hg2 is not difficult. The vector of unknown biomechanical parameters includes two parameters, kφ and cφ.

caption.p: Fitting results, motion frequency response function.

sec.p: The simple 1-DOF model is able to fit rather well the modulus of the measured motion FRF in the range 0.5–4 Hz, which includes the main resonance peak. Large errors are present above 4 Hz, because the modulus of the measured FRF tends to zero for very large frequencies, whereas the calculated FRF has a finite limit.

When the experimental data are fitted by means of the 2-DOF model, the same inertial properties of the 1-DOF model are used, but the vector of unknown parameters includes four parameters: kφ, cφ, ky and cy.
This model fits well the modulus of the measured motion FRF in the whole frequency range. The fitting of phase is sufficient at low frequency, but at high frequency it shows an error of about 150°.

Fitting results presented in Figure 11 were obtained setting phase weight wmφ to 0.25. Some attempts were made to improve phase fitting by using higher phase weights. The results were not satisfactory, because fitting of modulus worsened and negligible improvements in fitting of phase were obtained.

If the 3-DOF model is used for fitting the motion FRF, there are six unknown parameters: kψ, cψ, kφ, cφ, ky and cy. Results, which are shown in Figure 11, highlight a good fitting of modulus (like the one obtained by means of the 2-DOF model) and a rather good fitting of phase, which does not shows large errors at high frequency. The weighting factor of phase (wmφ) was typically 0.25.

Actually, the introduction of the third mode of vibration in the description of the trunk makes it possible to obtain a good fit both in terms of modulus and phase. Some differences in the phase at low frequency may be caused by reflex dynamics. It is worth pointing out that reflex dynamics is more important in roll tests that in other tests,4,17 because in the former the rider’s balance is affected.
Finally, the motion and the torque FRFs are fitted by means of the 5-DOF model.

The penalty function includes both the term related to the motion FRF and the term related to the torque FRF. The vector of unknown parameters is composed of fourteen terms: kψ, cψ, kφ, cφ, ky, cy, ka, ca, kf, cf, kθa, cθa, kθf and cθf.
The fitting of the motion FRF is good in the whole frequency range, and it is similar to the one obtained by means of the 3-DOF model.

If the torque FRF is considered (Figure 12), the fitting of modulus is good in the range 2–8 Hz that includes the first minimum, the maximum and the second minimum. Above 8 Hz the calculated FRF is not able to reproduce the measured increment in FRF amplitude, perhaps because it does not model a resonance of some subsystem of the rider’s body. In the low frequency range (<2 Hz) the calculated torque FRF has large values when the frequency tends to zero as the measured FRF, then the calculated torque FRF shows a small resonance peak at about 1.5 Hz; this frequency is close to the one of the main resonance peak of the motion FRF. The measured torque FRF shows only a variation in slope at 1.5 Hz. Nevertheless it is worth highlighting that the mean torque FRF is here considered, but some riders (see Figures 3 and 5) actually showed a peak in the torque FRF between 1.5 and 2 Hz. Perhaps the voluntary control plays an important role at low frequency and the theoretical torque FRF is more consistent with a particular behaviour of some riders. The 5-DOF model is able to fit with enough accuracy the phase of the torque FRF, but there are some differences in the range 2–3 Hz.

caption.p: Fitting results, torque frequency response function.

sec.p: Table 1 summarizes the calculated mass properties and the stiffness and damping parameters of the mean rider identified by means of the various models.

caption.p: Calculated and identified parameters, standard and increased grasping force.

sec.p: In the 1- and 2-DOF models, kφ,cφ, ky and cy are parallel stiffness and damping of trunk and arms, whereas in the 3- and 5-DOF models they are attributed to the trunk. The constant geometric properties of the models are
The 1-DOF and 2-DOF models give similar values of lean stiffness (kφ) and damping (cφ).

If the biomechanical parameters are identified by means of the 3-DOF model, lean stiffness (kφ) decreases, whereas lean damping (cφ) increases. The third DOF has a large influence on the lateral stiffness and damping (ky and cy), which decrease markedly. The connection between the two parts of the trunk shows large stiffness (kψ) and very small damping (cψ).

The parameters of the 5-DOF model are summarized in the last column of Table 1. The stiffness and damping parameters of the trunk are similar to the ones of the 3-DOF model. The sharing out of stiffness and damping between upper arm and forearm is particular. Both in the lateral and in the torsion direction the stiffness and damping associated with the upper arms are much smaller than the ones associated with the forearms. This distribution of stiffness and damping is consistent with the small influence of the main resonance of the trunk on the torque on the handlebars, since the low stiffness and damping of upper arms limit the transmitted torque. This distribution is consistent with the peak of the handlebars torque at about 5 Hz, which corresponds to a resonance of the arms generated by the mass of the elbows and the stiffness of forearms.

sec.title: Tests with increased grasping force
sec.p: The shape of the motion FRF measured with increased grasping force is similar to the one of the FRF measured with standard grasping force, but there is the displacement of the main peak towards the high frequencies; the fitting model has to take into account this interesting phenomenon.
Fitting results are summarized in Figure 13.

caption.p: Fitting results, motion frequency response function, increased grasping force.

sec.p: The 1-DOF model in this condition also gives a rather good fitting of the modulus of the motion FRF in the low frequency range. The 2-DOF model gives a very good fitting of modulus in the whole frequency range and a poor fitting of phase.
If the 3-DOF model is used for fitting the motion FRF a relevant improvement in the fitting of phase is achieved.
These models take into account the displacement of the main resonance peak caused by the increased grasping force.

The 5-DOF model makes it possible to fit both the motion and the torque FRF measured in the presence of increased grasping force. Figure 13 shows that the fitting of the motion FRF is good both in terms of modulus and phase. Figure 14 shows that the calculated torque FRF is able to represent the most important features of the measured one, but there are differences in the amplitude of the main peak and some differences in modulus and phase in the range 3–5 Hz.

caption.p: Fitting results, torque frequency response function, increased grasping force.

sec.p: Fitting parameters are summarized in Table 1. In the models without a detailed description of arms the increased grasping force leads to increases in stiffness and damping parameters.

The analysis of the parameters identified by means of the 5-DOF model shows a very different behaviour of the rider’s body in the presence of increased grasping force. Most of the parameters of the trunk (kφ, cφ, ky, cy) show small variations; kψ decreases, cψ increases. The stiffness and damping parameters of upper arms show a very large increase. The stiffness parameters of forearms increase, whereas the damping parameters decrease. Actually, in the presence of an increased grasping force, the upper arms become an important path of transmission of roll oscillations to the rider’s body.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The FRF of the lean motion of the rider’s body measured in the presence of roll excitation shows a main resonance peak at 2 Hz and large amplitudes up to 6 Hz, which are affected by the grasping force the rider exerts on the handlebars. The FRF of the torque on the handlebars (in the roll direction) is not simply correlated with the motion FRF.

Various models have been used for fitting the experimental results. First, the motion FRF has been fitted. The 1-DOF model is very simple, requires the knowledge of the mass properties of trunk, head and arms only, and it is able to fit the modulus of the measured motion FRF in the range of the main resonance peak. Hence, it may be enough to simulate the response of the rider’s body in the study of weave phenomena, which typically takes place below 4 Hz. The 2-DOF model requires the same information about mass distribution of the rider’s body and gives a good fitting of the modulus of measured motion FRF data up to 10 Hz, in the presence of both normal and increased grasping force.

The 3-DOF model is able to fit well both the modulus and the phase of the measured motion FRF in the whole frequency range. The 5-DOF model, which includes a detailed description of arms, is able to fit both the motion FRF and the torque FRF. It gives interesting information about the variations in the distribution of stiffness and damping that take place when the grasping force increases.
Further studies will deal with the actual implementation of these models in the multi-body models of two wheeled vehicles.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: em fitting error of modulus
eφ fitting error of phase
h2 height of the joint dividing the trunk
hE,lE elbow height and distance
hg2, hg3 centre of mass height of body 2 and 3
hhb handlebars offset
Jxx2, Jxx3, Jxx4 moments of inertia of the biomechanical models body
ka,ca upper arms lateral stiffness and damping
kf, cf forearms lateral stiffness and damping
ky, cy lateral stiffness and damping
kθa,cθa upper arms rotational stiffness and damping
kθf,cθf forearms rotational stiffness and damping
kφcφ lean stiffness and damping
kψcψ internal stiffness and damping of the trunk

m
1
lower body mass
m2,m3,m4 masses of the biomechanical models

M
hb
torque on the handlebars

P
( x )
penalty function

P
m
( x )
penalty function (motion frequency response function)

( x )

,wτ,wmφ,wτφ fitting weighting factors

sec.title: Matrices of 5-DOF model
sec.p: in which Jxx4=m4(lE/2)2 is the moment of inertia of the two lumped masses of the elbows that are connected by the massless bar and rotate in a plane parallel to the rider’s trunk and lE is the distance between elbows.
in which hE is elbow height.
